ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My conversational Spanish improved greatly. I feel more able to engage in meaningful conversation and read and understand Spanish texts. I am also more cognizant of disadvantaged groups and Spanish works regarding these topics.
I enjoyed Spanish this semester. I continued on my path towards language mastery, and developing my speaking and writing skills.

In this class, I further developed my ability to speak, read, and write Spanish. This course used a range of resources and exercises (movies, podcasts, books, and articles) to help me learn about themes of migration, indigenous culture, and the role of women in the Spanish-speaking world.
Taught me new grammatical skills that are important in Spanish

I think my Spanish speaking and listening abilities improved substantially. I also gained knowledge of some new verb tenses and nouns. Additionally, I learned something about some important topics in the Spanish-speaking world, including immigration, the situations of native peoples, and representations of/by women in art.
Spanish
I learned a lot about Spanish culture, representation of women in art and immigration.

Much stronger speaking ability, overall confidence in using the Spanish language 
Talking about various social issues in Spanish

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is very conversational. I far prefer this style as opposed to grammar activities. The nightly homework was a perfect amount. It was not overwhelming, but it improved my engagement with the class and improved my language skills. No weaknesses come to mind.

I really enjoyed the class. I felt that the homework made sense and was related to the material we learned in class, which was awesome. In some past Spanish classes, the work we did out of class felt disconnected from the work we did in class. That was not the case here. In class, we often had very interesting class discussions. This was an aspect I really enjoyed.

Strengths: Learning grammar and expanding vocabulary indirectly through materials focused on subjects, rather than a direct study of language rules. 

Weaknesses: Seminars benefit from the commitment and activate participation of all members of the class. Without this engagement, the class felt slow, awkward, and boring at times.

The structure of the course was poor. In real life if you make mistakes when speaking or writing you correct yourself and move on. However in this class you were punished for mistakes in grammar or speaking by points being taken off. This is to no fault of my professor, it is the fault of the department. The way that Spanish is taught here does not foster an environment of learning what so ever.

Strengths: very engaging classes, good preparatory activities, interesting assignments.

Weaknesses: none really

Strengths: small group discussions
Weaknesses: some of the topics can be hard to discuss with limited Spanish vocab knowledge

SPAN 140 (and Profe Russell) was especially great for growing my speaking abilities 

I wish there was more of a repetitive focus on learning verb tenses, as we were introduced to various new verb tenses this semester but I never memorized any of them or felt comfortable using them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. L4 Spanish is the best I have encountered in the sequence. It feels far less tedious, and I enjoyed practicing the language in this seminar-based course.
I would. Many people will just be taking it for their language requirement, but I also plan to continue into L5 Spanish.
Yes. I appreciate how L4 Spanish departs from conventional grammar and spelling instruction. Instead, this class requires a level of critical thinking and engagement that I would rewarding.

No. If you want to learn spanish there are easier ways that will not cause you as much stress as spanish at Yale has. The department needs a systematic reboot to its antiquated way of teaching the language
Yes, I think this was an excellent course for anyone looking to improve their Spanish above L3, especially if you take it with Prof. Russell.
nah
Yes! If you are interested in bettering your confidence in speaking in Spanish and more real world information about Spanish speaking countries I highly recommend this class.
Absolutely!
Definitely! If somebody is looking to improve their ability to speak Spanish, this course is really great.
